attributes.magic: ELF 32-bit MSB executable, Motorola m68k, 68020, version 1 (SYSV), statically linked, stripped

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects suspicious single byte XORed keyword 'Mozilla/5.0' - it uses yara's XOR modifier and therefore cannot print the XOR key. You can use the CyberChef recipe linked in the reference field to brute force the used key.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects suspicious single byte XORed keyword 'Mozilla/5.0' - it uses yara's XOR modifier and therefore cannot print the XOR key. You can use the CyberChef recipe linked in the reference field to brute force the used key.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis: This ELF binary is a malicious botnet agent, likely part of the Mirai or Gafgyt families. It features high-level obfuscation and anti-analysis techniques, evidenced by the use of unconventional instructions such as DAA (Decimal Adjust After Addition) and DAS (Decimal Adjust After Subtraction), as well as raw I/O port instructions (__outsd, __outsb) in the decompiled HLIL. The binary is statically linked and lacks standard library imports, typical of standalone malware. Concrete IOCs include HTTP request templates targeting '/cdn-cgi/', which is a common technique for mimicking legitimate Cloudflare traffic or performing C2 check-ins, and references to '/dev/null' for silencing command output.
